concept.title: Data Visibilities
concept.shortdesc: Data visibilities identify the privacy requirements for data.

conbody.p: Data visibility should be defined in your organization's governance policy and is configured in by the .
comes with three data visibilities predefined:

row.entry: Sensitive data that contains identifying information. Such data should be secured and available only to authorized personnel.
Sensitive data that has been transformed and masked to remove identifying information
Data that does not contain sensitive or identifying data.

conbody.p: You can define additional data visibilities to suit your organization's needs. Possible examples are CONFIDENTIAL to identify data that is sensitive and requires a user to a certain level of access or certification to access, PII to identify Personally Identifiable Information, PHI to identify personal health information, or SECRET to identify especially sensitive material.
conbody.note: Once defined, a data visibility may be neither edited nor deleted.
conbody.p: The data visibilities specified for a data source are referred to in access policies and matched against user authorizations to determine what actions, if any, a given user is allowed to perform on the data. The access policy can then be applied to a data source or dataset during system configuration.

In addition, any data visibility defined in the system can be used by a Data Processing Function (DPF) to tag any derived data fields. These derived data elements can be assigned different privacy levels from the data source and from one another. For example, the Social Security Number extracted from a health record can be tagged CONFIDENTIAL if that data visibility has been defined in the system. This mechanism provides "cell-level" privacy protection.
